case_vignette: A 20-year-old college student presents to his student health clinic complaining of a scaly rash on his right inner thigh. He reports that the rash is itchy and first appeared 4 months ago. A similar rash occurred last year, which improved with a topical cream he purchased over the counter, but he does not remember the name. The patient has a history of attention deficient disorder and atopic dermatitis. His medications include methylphenidate and betamethasone. The patient has been a wrestler since high school and currently wrestles for the university. He reports he is doing well in his classes. He admits to smoking marijuana recreationally and having a few beers on the weekends with his friends. He went to Costa Rica for a 2-week mission trip 6 months ago. Physical exam reveals a lesion as shown in Figure A. Potassium hydroxide scrapings of the lesion confirm the diagnosis.
question: Which  is the best treatment for the patient's most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a scaly rash on my right inner thigh that's itchy, and it first showed up about 4 months ago.
Have you noticed the rash spreading or changing in appearance since it first appeared?
No, I haven't noticed it spreading or changing in appearance since it first appeared.
Have you tried any treatments or remedies for your rash so far?
Yes, I used a topical cream from the pharmacy last year when a similar rash occurred, and it got better, but I don't remember the name of the cream.
Are there any other areas on your body where you've experienced a similar rash, either now or in the past?
No, I've only had a similar rash on the same spot last year.
Do you have any known allergies or a personal or family history of skin conditions like eczema or psoriasis?
I have a history of atopic dermatitis.
Have you had any recent infections, been on antibiotics, or experienced changes in your health besides the rash?
No, I haven't had any recent infections, been on antibiotics, or experienced other changes in my health.
Is the area with the rash painful, do you have any fever, or have there been any blisters or open sores?
No, the area with the rash is not painful, and I don't have a fever, blisters, or open sores.
Is the skin rash circular in shape and does it have a clearer center?
Yes, the rash is circular in shape with a clearer center.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea cruris (jock itch)
